title: Adaptive Linearly Constrained Minimum Variance Volumetric Active Noise Control
author: Manan Mittal (Stony Brook University), Ryan M. Corey (University of Illinois Chicago), Andrew C. Singer (Stony Brook University), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces an adaptive algorithm for active noise control which could enhance the restoration and enhancement of audio signals, applicable in Haohe Liu's work on speech and audio processing.
background: Enhancing audio environments by using adaptive algorithms to minimize unwanted noise throughout a three-dimensional space instead of just at specific locations.
contribution: This paper introduces a time-domain formulation for linearly constrained minimum variance active noise control (LCMV-ANC) to solve the problem of ineffective spatial response shaping, achieving effective noise suppression with spatial constraints.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods typically focused only on uniformly weighted error minimization or required ideal assumptions about acoustic paths, limiting flexibility.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work allows for constraints at specific locations, enhancing flexibility and effectiveness in noise suppression without rigid assumptions.

key_innovation: The method employs a time-domain structure for adaptive filtering that directly incorporates spatial constraints, leading to more effective volumetric noise control.
real_world_impact: The proposed adaptive noise control method can significantly improve noise suppression in environments like vehicles or public spaces, enhancing user experience and communication clarity.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the author.

new_terms.linearly constrained minimum variance: **Linearly constrained minimum variance** refers to an optimization approach that minimizes signal variance while meeting certain predefined conditions.
new_terms.filtered-X least mean squares: **Filtered-X Least Mean Squares (FxLMS)** is an adaptive filtering algorithm that compensates for distortions in the secondary path before updating filter coefficients.
